contentList.content: Your Armour Class is reduced by [1] while you are not Wet. Armour Class is increased by [2] while you are Wet.
While under the effect of Mage Armour, your spells and cantrips that deal[1] can inflict Magical Bleeding on the target (even if the target is immune to bleeding).
Summon a minor water elemental that excels at dealing[1] at any distance.
When you use Champion's Challenge, affected foes also become Frightened for [1] turns.
Respond to a foe that misses you in melee range by immediately using Blinding Smite against them — consuming a Channel Oath charge.
Summon a greater water elemental that excels at dealing[1] at any distance.
Your spells or cantrips that deal[1] also deal [2].
When you take[1], deal [2] to the attacker.
Your attacks with levelled spells that deal[1] also deal [2].
Your attacks also deal [1] while you have less than [2]% HP.
Your attacks also deal [1] while you have more than [2]% HP.
Your spells or cantrips that deal[1] also deal [2] while you have less than [3]% HP.
Your spells or cantrips that deal[1] also deal [2] while you have more than [3]% HP.
When you miss a foe with an attack, you still deal [1] to them.
When you critically miss a foe with an attack, you still deal [1] to them.
While you are affected by STATUS, your attacks also deal [1].
While wearing heavy armor and a shield, all damage you take is reduced by [1].

Psionic powers teleport all valuable items within [1] to the wearer.

This feature can be toggled in the passive effects tab.

As thy hands, trembling with ancient anticipation, placed the purple-black helm upon thy crown, a most peculiar sensation befell thee — as if the very boundaries betwixt mortal flesh and the ethereal realms had grown thin. 'Twas akin to witnessing the great ice - floes of the Northern Wastes yield to spring's unstoppable advance, or to sailing the perilous currents of the Astral Plane aboard a vessel crafted of naught but ritual and will. A most curious chill descended upon thy fingertips, reaching deep unto bone and marrow, whilst within the helm's secretive confines, an entity not of mortal origin began to weave its psionic tapestry of power and intent. What ancient might, what forgotten arts shall this eldritch discovery bestow upon its bearer? Verily, the answer lies in the whispers of destiny that now encircle thy thoughts.

Hello! This collection features new equipment created as part of the final expansion — RICHER BUILDS. Let me briefly explain why I'm creating it.

Progression Balance
Many players often complained to me in the comments on the mod page on mod.io (where you can also visit me, but please address in English) that even with the random nature of the mod, they assembled decent builds too rarely. This is understandable - after all, synergies in the random pool are not sufficiently condensed. Imagine: 1200 items, and almost each has a unique mechanic. This affects progression balance, how you strengthen over time, and therefore it's very important to make synergies denser, more saturated. In this regard, I decided to focus specifically on equipment, finally reaching the total number of new artifacts to +1000 pieces — and to do this in the shortest possible time, conserving time resources.

Time Resources
It's no secret that I work on the mod alone, nobody helps me. Accordingly, to accelerate content release, I need to compress some tasks, leaving them for later. For example, I still can't bring cloak icons to the new format or finish a couple of cool VFX for old artifacts. I'm going to do the same here: remove too costly operations from the workflow, leaving only the most important.

Most Important
Gameplay remains the most important. You want to see many new good items for your favorite synergies, would like to see new ones; and many. Therefore, as part of the final expansion, I'll try to use a minimum of new assets: such as icons, unique names, or flavor text. This is the most time-consuming part as it requires a deep creative process. The focus is only on the gameplay component, what will make mere item a truly useful magical artifact. I would not mind, say, adding many new items to the collection. But as long as I'm the only one creating it - the process won't be quick, which means it doesn't make sense in this format.

Help
I'm still collecting player votes (link to Google Forms is in the mod description) on which synergies I should develop before completely finishing work on the collection. Mostly these are ideas I'm willing to add, that's my author's vision, but of course, I'll consider other synergies to add to the survey. You could help with this, choose several options you like, let me know how you feel the game. Thank you. And thank you for using the BG3 Revolution.

Summon fresh artifacts from the new expansion. New items use assets from existing artifacts.

If you see these items, you won't encounter them randomly in the world anymore!
Call upon the mighty patron of the winter folk, becoming invulnerable until you deal damage to another.

Affected entity can't be targeted by enemy attacks or spells. However, it can still take damage from spells that influence a larger area. Condition ends if the affected entity attacks or harms another creature, and will receive Frost Bulwark Blocked for [1] turns.
Affected entity can't receive <LSTag Type="Status" Tooltip="AMP_SANCTUARY">Frost Bulwark</LSTag>.
While there are no allies within [1] of you, become immune to[2], frozen surface effects and Wet status.
You are immune to[1], cannot slip on ice, and cannot be wet.
While standing on a frozen surface, regain [1] at the end of each turn.
While standing on a frozen surface, regains [1].

Using <LSTag Type="Spell" Tooltip="Throw_Telekinesis">Telekinesis</LSTag>, you can spend a <LSTag Type="ActionResource" Tooltip="ReactionActionPoint">reaction point</LSTag> to trigger a surge of <LSTag Tooltip="WildMagic">wild magic</LSTag> on yourself.
Trigger a surge of <LSTag Tooltip="WildMagic">wild magic</LSTag> after moving the target.
%%% CHOOSE A CULTURALLY APPROPRIATE NAME, JACK BONES STRICTLY FOR USA AUDIENCE %%%
Raise an applause-hungry skeletal duelist from a nearby corpse.
Jack Bones stitched this necromancer's robe from theater curtains after death, binding his soul to seek eternal applause. Wear it near a corpse, and he'll take his final bow once more.
Whenever an undead dies within [1] of you, it triggers a Confusion wave in a [2] radius.

A young shaman of the Stormcaller clan spent months observing tempests in the mountain pass, recording every flash, every strike — until lightning struck him directly, leaving only a melted medallion at the center of scorched earth. His companions found him three days later, wandering the slopes and muttering about "the dance between strikes." Inside the amulet still beats the storm he caught — that final one.
%%% DONT TOUCH STUFF BELOW, STILL IN DEVELOPMENT!!!! %%%
You cannot be knocked prone and are not slowed on difficult terrain. You do not provoke opportunity attacks while carrying a bow.

Vludber, the only halfling to become an honorary chieftain of the Spine of the World bugbear tribe, possessed a unique gift of tailoring his jokes to any audience, be it a noble assembly or a troll's den. The bugbears still perform his 'Laughing Giant Dance' during important ceremonies, though none have achieved the mastery of the original.
When you use actions, all foes within 5m around you must pass an Intelligence saving throw (4) or be overcome with terrible laughter for 2 turns. [Charisma +1(22)]
If you are a githyanki or disguised as one, accumulate Astral Tirelessness each turn in combat. After accumulating 10 charges, you can spend them to restore a rage charge. [Strength +1(22)]
If you are not wearing armor and a shield, gain +2 to Armor Class.

This elegant plumed hat belonged to a famous northern diplomat whose peace negotiations saved more lives than the swords of the greatest heroes. Neverwinter tavern regulars remember how visitors would forget their initial purposes, spending hours in conversations with a man who valued every opinion, regardless of the speaker's origins.
All burning objects within 15m of you are instantly extinguished. Constitution increases for each turn spent in shadows during combat, up to +3.

These ancient boots were crafted by Netherese wizards studying the limits of transmutation magic. Their creator willingly turned himself to stone, but his will continued to resonate through the rock, creating powerful vibrations capable of crushing enemies. Heavy metallic plates are built into the soles specifically to amplify this effect.
When you are Petrified, at the start of each of your turns in combat, your stone body creates powerful vibrations, dealing [1] to all foes within [2].
Powerful vibrations emanate from the petrified body, creating destructive sonic waves.
When you kill a creature, you can cast a spell of any Level without expending or having a spell slot.

Magical runes envelop the metal of this slender one-handed hammer, covering almost its entire surface with a bright blue glow. When you touched the handle, you immediately jerked your hand away - it shocks! But after getting used to it, you even found it had a light massaging effect. Of all the runes you tried to decipher, you could only translate one word - Rrangundyr, whatever that means.

After gaining more than [1] Lightning Charges, you charge your next attack of any type, which will create an explosion in a [2] radius, dealing [4] to all creatures and electrifying surfaces. An affected creature can halve the damage if it suceed a Dexterity Saving Throw ([3]).
Every facet of this filigree sword gleams like gold, and the blade is honed to such perfection that one can even hear the light musical ringing of the blade in battle.
When attacking foes in combat with this sword, you gain [1] stack of Cadence, increasing weapon damage.

+[1] weapon damage per stack of this effect.

If you have more than [2] stacks when attacking, you will unleash a resonant melody and deal [3] to all creatures within [4]. An affected creature can halve the damage if it succeed a Dexterity Saving Throw ([5]).
On hit with thrown attacks or unarmed attacks, the wielder gains Lightning Charges x[1].

For a millennium, the Verdant Watch has stood vigil in the Chondathan Wood, where ancient tree-pollen forms an armor harder than mithral upon their sacred plates. Their eternal duty: to contain the Rotting Heart, that corrupted seed of the primordial forest which pulses with malevolent life in the deepwood's forbidden groves.
If you didn't move on your turn in combat, regain [1] at the end of your turn.
Removed when moving. Regains [1] at the end of each turn.

The death-priests of ancient Thay wove these vestments from the burial shrouds of a thousand martyrs who died in ecstasy, their souls willingly surrendered to the Bone Throne. Each thread pulses with thanaturgic essence — the concentrated joy of those who embraced oblivion as liberation. To wear it is to become a conduit between the living and the grateful dead.

If a foe successfully resists your necromancy spell, regain an Action Point.
+[1] to Spell Save DC.

At the start of your turn, while you have Channel Divinity charges, regain [1] (even if you are undead).

Effectiveness scales with Wisdom modifier.

When Archmage Khalandros breached the Far Realm seeking the Primordial Equation, reality itself recoiled from his hubris. His robes became a living paradox — threads woven from possibility itself, shifting through spectrums beyond mortal perception. Those who wear them report seeing colors that have no names, hearing the whispers of spells yet uncast.
When scoring a Critical Hit with a spell or cantrip, regain random Spell Slots of [1]~[2] levels with a small chance.
When a foe critically misses you, wild magic chaos warps reality — your next attack becomes a Critical Hit.
Wild magic has warped reality — your next attack will be a <LSTag Tooltip="CriticalHit">Critical Hit</LSTag>.

In the shadow-draped halls of Castle Ravenloft, nine noble bloodlines willingly offered their scions to sanctify this vestment. Blind oracles wove moonless silk with threads drawn from willing veins, each stitch a prayer to the eternal night. The robe remembers its baptism — that cursed eve when mortality became a distant dream.
When dealing damage with Vampire Bite or Vampiric Touch, you additionally deal [1].

"Thus ended the glorious campaign against the treacherous Ghergs" — so the victors' histories record the extinction of an entire people. General Alierghast called them savages, barbarians, a threat to civilization. The truth died with them: they were farmers, poets, healers. Alierghast's own son knew this — he had secretly wed a Gherg woman, learning their gentle ways before war consumed everything. When she burned with her people, he spent twelve broken years trying to resurrect the dead. The ritual failed, but left this cursed mantle — woven from ashes and grief, holding fragments of the murdered innocent.
Call forth the spirit of a Gherg ancestor, seeking justice for their slaughtered people. The phantom weakens as it struggles to remain in the world that forgot them.
A mournful Gherg spirit appears beside the attacker, fighting your foes with the desperate fury of the extinct. Each turn weakens its fragile hold on existence.

If you are a human or half-elf (or disguised as one), gain +[1] Reaction Point.

You can spend a reaction when you or an ally are hit to summon a grieving Gherg spirit.

In the deepest forges of Mithral Hall, where rivers of molten adamantine flow like water, master smiths wrought this armor from meteoric iron blessed by Clangeddin himself. Each plate was tempered in dragonfire and quenched in the tears of stone giants. The Silverbeard clan presented it to their greatest champions — those who stood alone against the darkness and prevailed.
You gain permanent <LSTag Type="Status" Tooltip="MAG_BLADE_WARD">Blade Ward</LSTag>.

Vallen Despana earned no glory in Menzoberranzan's arena — she earned exile. A century of mercenary work yielded a hundred conquered foes, and from each she claimed a single plate of armor. In the forges of Skullport, she had them reforged into this impossible suit: each piece molecularly realigned to create armor that moves like shadowsilk yet deflects like adamantine. "Every plate," she would say, "is a life I took. Every life, a lesson learned."

If you are a drow (or disguised as one), gain +[1] Movement Speed, +[3] to Weapon Attack Rolls and +[2]% to Jump distance. Additionally, wearing this armor as a drow also grants immunity to Opportunity Attacks and [2]% reduction to fall damage.

"Case #847: Prisoner discovered dimensional glitch in Cell B-12. Subject began duplicating bread loaves exponentially. Upon breach: 14 tons of baked goods. Subject near death from starvation — no bread touched. Note: Robe's enchantment prevents removal once worn. Consider for repeat offenders." — Crumpled note from Waterdeep Prison archives.

When your HP drops below [1]% in combat, all foes within [2] must succeed a Wisdom Saving Throw ([3]) or become Paralyzed for [4] turns.

Triggers no more than once per combat.
Paralyze all creatures within [1] radius of the cursed robe's wearer.

The cosmic scales of justice tip against you — this cursed vestment binds to your very soul. Once donned, it cannot be removed by any mortal means. Consider it your scarlet letter, your mark of shame, your eternal "kick me" sign from the universe itself.

Before the gods walked Toril, before fire knew warmth, the First Winter descended. From its heart arose the Throne of Absolute Zero, and upon it sat the Nameless King — neither living nor undead, but something between. His plate mail was forged from meteoric ice that fell when stars still dreamed, each piece a fragment of cosmic winter given form.

When dealing [1], you also deal [2].
You become the Nameless King.
While standing on a frozen surface, use Wall of Ice for free once per turn.

Your flesh undergoes lichdom's lesser transformation. You gain Immunity to[1], Resistance to[2], and cannot be affected by Paralysis, Poison, Bleeding, Sleep, Charm, or other conditions that don't affect Undead. You also cannot heal yourself using the methods of the living.
Your Misty Steps are used for free in combat.

Within the steel vessel, luminous essence swirls in patterns older than memory. The gear-toothed seal bears an artificer's mark — etched runes speaking of transmutation and binding, of power distilled from the very breath of dying stars. A faint warmth emanates through the tempered glass, as if something within yet dreams of the forge that birthed it.

When you deal[1] with Weapon Attacks, the target must succeed on a Constitution Saving Throw or you regain a Bonus Action Point.

The DC effectiveness depends on your Maneuver Save DC.
Each turn in combat, gain Charged Catalyst to cast your next levelled spell without consuming a Spell Slot.
Your next levelled spell costs no Spell Slot. When you cast a spell, take [1].
While affected by any Madness condition, your unarmed attacks are always Critical Hits.
Instantly swap places with target creature in combat. If the target succeeds on an Intelligence Saving Throw ([1]), you become Stunned.
Whenever you recieve any condition in combat, create a [1] Hellfire surface around you for [2] turns.
When you damage a wounded enemy, you take [1].
While drunk, the number you need to roll to land a Critical Hit with unarmed attacks is reduced by [1].
When you miss a foe, all creatures within [1] (including yourself) must succeed on a Strength Saving Throw ([2]) or become Petrified for [3] turns.

You charm a creature you damage — if it fails a Wisdom Saving Throw, for [1] turns.

The DC effectiveness depends on your Maneuver Save DC.
When a creature within [1] of you takes[2], it must succeed on a Constitution Saving Throw ([3]) or recieve Radiating Orb for [4] turns.
All your leveled spells also make targets Wet for [1] turns.
While an allied fiend is within [2] of you, both of you also deal [1] with all damage sources.
You also deal [1] with all damage sources.
When you deal[1], the target must succeed on a Wisdom Saving Throw ([2]) or become Confused for [3] turns.
Your Melee Weapon Attacks also deal [1], if you have any curse affecting you. (Damage type depends on your equipped weapon)
Whenever you Restrain a creature, create a [1] radius Web surface nearby for [2] turns.
While standing in thick flower growth, you are Immune to being Stunned.
When you kill a creature, you gain Devil's Sight for [1] turns.
When you use Dash, you are immediately transformed into a Sheep.
When you cast Blink, you have a [1]% chance to summon a friendly Beholder. The Beholder's connection to the material plane weakens each turn.

When you push a creature, push it [1] further.

Pushing includes any forced movement, even from spells.
If you are a human or half-elf (or disguised as one), your jump range outside combat increases by [1] and you gain permanent Invisibility outside combat.
If you are Tiny, when you cast Fireball or Flame Strike, gain Fire Mastery.

Your next <LSTag Type="Spell" Tooltip="Projectile_Fireball">Fireball</LSTag> or <LSTag Type="Spell" Tooltip="Target_FlameStrike">Flame Strike</LSTag> can be cast without expending <LSTag Tooltip="SpellSlot">Spell Slots</LSTag>.

Grimland was Twinsreach once. Heartland Folk and Coast Dwellers built it together, different but whole. Then came the Speaking Stones. Every voice heard at once. Every bitter word echoed back tenfold.

The Heartlands heard mockery. The Coasts heard hate. Truth drowned in the noise.

The Dividers got rich selling rage. Neighbors became enemies. Enemies became nothing. When the burning stopped, both sides had won. Both sides had lost.

This cloak comes from that nowhere place. They say it changes color depending who looks at it. They say a lot of things in Grimland. Nobody listens anymore.
While bearing any curse, you are enlarged.
